By MARC DUVOISIN
Student Council President
Andy
Savitz and others
affiliated with the Hopkins
Union have called into question
the need for retaining the Union
Governing Board, charging that
the Board has scheduled events in
conflict with the SC Social
Committee to the detriment of
the Council.
Savitz contended that the
Governing Board is no longer
providing just "supplemental"
programming, as it had pledged it
would. "The Board told me," he
explained, "in full session, no
less, that they would provide
supplemental scheduling. They
told me, in effect, 'if there's an
empty room we'll fill it.'"
"But now" he continued,
"they're in an adversary position.
They're filling our rooms.
They're competing with Student
Council activities."
"The night we had a dance in
the Great Hall, the Governing
Board had an event in the
Rathskeller which was drawing
away from us."
Hopkins Union Director Alan
Sapakie contended, however,
that the Governing Board is not
infringing on the Council's
domain.
"The Union Governing Board
best represents activities for the
entire community, not just
undergraduates. We complement
the Student Council's activities,
we do not compete with them,"
said Sapakie.
SC Treasurer Alan "Fink
concurred with Savitz, noting "I
don't like to see other activities
hurt by the Governing Board."
"I don't like," he continued,
"to see a Union event like the
Wizard of Oz curtail the
Barnstormers production. I
sincerely question the role of the
Union Governing Board as a
'supplementary' programmer."
Savitz asserted that "the Board
has really outlived its usefulness
once it has set up priorities and
policies for the Union." He
revealed that "If I feel that the
Board is continuing to violate its
self-avowed principle of

providing supplemental
entertainment, I will consider
abolishing it."
"Legally, I could do it," he
said. "By withdrawing
undergraduate representation on
the Board, I could effectively kill
the Board."
Disagreement
Student members of the
Board, however, disagreed with
Savitz's assessment.
"People shouldn't worry about
who's scheduling what," said Bob
Ivanhoe. 'The Student Council
should not feel threatened by the
Governing Board."
Tim Oldfield, last year's Board
Chairman asserted that the Board
"represents every facet of the
Hopkins community," in allusion
to the diverse membership of the
panel.
Savitz, though, asserted that
the conflict with the Board could
damage student support for the
Council. "Much of our support
accrues from the social programs
we provide. The Board will hurt
us-by overriding our activities."

BY LAINY STEPHANS
The two students in charge of
last year's yearbook, Hullabaloo,
may be held accountable for the
loss of $2,000 incurred by the
publication.

Mirman and the Business
Manager Glenn Pantell neglected
to have Alan Sapakie, Director of

clear grounds to hold them
accountable."
If, however, the contract was
properly authorized, Fink
maintains this loss will be used as
a test case.

commented.

occurred through no attempt to
get community advertising

sell to parents and students."

"but we had trouble getting

By BOB DANNER
Seth Feltheimer, Senior Class
President and former Chairman
of the Student Council Film
Series, is initiating a new Senior
Class Film series which is
scheduled to begin this Friday.
The new program to be
chaired by Phillip Hammer, was
created "to give students a
choice." Feltheimer, who had set
up the SC films for the last two
years, is dissatisfied with the
present listings.
"I think it is disgusting that a
campus Hopkins' size can show
only one movie a week," he said.
"The movies are generally
poorer this year; if you don't like
what is playing on campus you
may be stuck with nothing to
do."
Feltheimer stated that he
thinks the number of films have
been reduced in order to increase
profits from the activity.
He stated that John

Cockerham, present chairman of
the SC Film Series, has
mismanaged the activity, and
that there is no need to reduce
the number of films shown.
"When I ran the series we had
at least one movie a week and
very often two. The program
showed a greater profit then than
it does now."
Hammer says he is hopeful for
the new series, but admitted
having trouble getting support.
"The SC and the Office of the
Chaplain have a monopoly on
rooms and projectors. It seems
that they are trying to limit
competition," Hammer
contended.
Cockerham was
"uninterested" in the Senior
Class Film Series and disagrees
with Feltheimer on several
points. He stated that the present
SC Film Series policy is not
based on profits, "though
financial considerations cannot
